body:
Perhaps change the learning rate schedule. Crank it down by quite a bit... 

'multi_step': [[0.005, 10000],
[0.02, 430000],
[0.002, 730000],
[0.001, 1030000]],


Perhaps from 0.005 to 0.00005 or so? Try if/when it blows up.

Thanks for your reply. But as so far, even if reducing the learning rate by 100 times (from 0.005 to 0.00005), it just increased the number of training iterations and delayed the time of reporting such error. It doesâ€˜t actually solve this problem.

That is strange - is there anything wrong about your labels & images? Did you check that there are any NANs in your labels (this should be done in Step4), that the labels fall outside the image (currently it does not check if they smaller than zero), etc...

The dataset and labels are all checked in step 3. There is nothing wrong about them. When I set lr to 0.00005, it could do 9k+ iters. Then I set lr to 0.000005, it has been running 21k+ iters. During the training process, lr has raised to 0.000002 after 10k iters. But the loss is no longer falling.

"The dataset and labels are all checked in step 3. "
Visually, but what if values are outside the image? Can you check them in the output file?
What is the size of your images?

This code has been used to train thousands of networks, odds are something is wrong with your labeled data set. This is a common issue, for many models, eg: https://github.com/tensorflow/models/issues/1881

rename.from: LossTensor is inf or nan while running my own dataset
rename.to: LossTensor is inf or nan while running my own dataset (Problem with data set)

body:
I think it is a training problem. In my case, I reduced learning rate further so the iteration can rise to 80K. But the loss is no longer falling any more when it reached around 0.18. As the training progress continues, the loss will gradually increase until inf and throw **LossTensor is inf or nan** problem. @AlexEMG can you give me some advise about training? Do I need to change the dataset or batch size and retrain? And I also want to know if the size of pic influence training effect because the height and width of my training data are all around 100~200px? 

multi_step:
-- [0.000005, 10000]
-- [0.00002, 20000]
-- [0.000003, 50000]
-- [0.000002, 100000]
-- [0.000001, 500000]
Just for reference of others, @cfanyyx wrote me a pm stating that it was related to a wrong configuration of TensorFlow.

I have the same issue now. I have used used deeplabcut on a few datasets successfully but I am now getting this issue suddenly when I try to train a new dataset. The issue now also occurs when I got back to previous datasets and configurations that worked in the past so maybe I have changed something about my tensorflow configuration. Do you know what about the tensorflow configuration was problematic and how I might get this working again?

@bouracha  The learning rate could be to high, or there might be nans, or infs in the labeling data. However, given some projects could be trained earlier, it seems that your TensorFlow is broken. Perhaps try to re-install it?

There are blanks in the training data (where bodyparts were occluded) but as are there also in an earlier project where training worked. I now get the same error when I try to re-do training on exactly that old dataset. So it does look like it's a problem with tensorflow but I have tried reinstalling it so I'm not sure...

By the way, this is the error (it pauses on 'Starting training' for about 30 seconds):

^ can you double check your collected_data file has no NaNs?

Yes, sorry I wasn't clear. It does have blanks which are nans at least when I open them up in pandas but these correspond to bodyparts that were not labelled for a given frame. The issue is that I seem to also have them in older datasets for which training did work and for which I have not altered the dataset.

If the problem is these nans what could I be doing wrong to create them? What should be in the train set where bodyparts are occluded?

For example, the first row of this training data corresponds to this image. I have not labelled the left hand as it can't be seen and as a result it's NaN in the training set.

![Screenshot from 2019-07-25 09-45-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17855974/61860041-2e497d00-aec1-11e9-9be7-f253e79f5d81.png)
They are blank when you label in our GUIs, not nans; nans would have never run on any version of tensorflow...
That is strange, I've started several new projects and it keeps creating them like this. I'll try once again but I presume a hacky solution is to just replace these nans with empty strings?

They are only nans when I read them into pandas. If I open them in libre office (see screenshot) They are blanks.... What are these blanks suppose to be?

![Screenshot from 2019-07-25 14-30-49](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17855974/61878645-48975100-aee9-11e9-8292-9f18152977c3.png)

and also in text editor..

![Screenshot from 2019-07-25 14-41-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17855974/61879126-5c8f8280-aeea-11e9-9a37-295938955633.png)
They should be blanks.
They are blanks here though..
Idk what happened to your h5 files. I would check the csvs, be sure all blank, then use the function convertcsvtoh5 to fix the h5s.
Wooooo, yes that worked! Thank you! Still no idea why my h5 files were consistently being corrupted however!
